content: The Alien Smuggling and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2007 may be cited as the official title. Key findings are outlined in the Act. The Alien Smuggling and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2007, also known as the official title, highlights the importance of aggressive enforcement against alien smuggling to protect US borders and national security. Congress recognizes alien smuggling as a transnational crime that threatens border integrity, sovereignty, and the rule of law. Special recognition is given to the Department of Homeland Security and the United States Border Patrol for their efforts in border security and anti-smuggling activities. The law enforcement community, including the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Justice, must have the necessary statutory tools to address security threats like alien smuggling. Special recognition is given to agencies like the United States Border Patrol and Customs and Border Protection for their efforts in border security. Alien smuggling poses a security threat that requires statutory tools for effective prosecution by the Justice Department. It also has a destabilizing effect on border communities, requiring collaboration with state and local law enforcement, medical personnel, social service providers, and the faith community. Existing penalties for alien smuggling are insufficient to punish smugglers adequately. Laws often fail to address the conduct of smugglers, transporters, recruiters, guides, and boat captains. Laws regarding failure to heave to are inadequate in punishing boat operators and crew. Existing laws are inadequate in punishing alien smugglers, transporters, recruiters, guides, and boat captains. The Department of Homeland Security will check alien smugglers and smuggled individuals against terrorist watchlists at U.S. borders. Additionally, there will be stronger prosecution and punishment for alien smugglers.
